properties.media:imagetext:
Water landings
A water landing is improbable while you are
flying in a Clipper, because it remains aloft on
any two of its four engines.
Just the same, Pan American's Clippers are
designed to withstand such landings. Airtight
wing tanks and cabin keep the aircraft afloat
long after you board life rafts. Ditched planes
have remained afloat for over a day and a half.
If trouble should arise, your Clipper Captain
will first radio for help. Next, he will inform
you-even though the situation is far from
serious. We believe in keeping every passenger
completely informed at all times.
Your safety instructions
Your Clipper crew has practiced many times
what to do in case of an emergency. Your part
is to cooperate quickly and completely.
The hundreds of pounds of the latest safety
equipment aboard your Clipper was tested be-
fore you boarded the plane. Instead of one life-
raft, there are four stowed away in a strategic
location. Each is outfitted with adequate food
and water. Even fishing tackle. There is also
a radio sending set which can send an SOS, con-
stantly, 2,000 miles in any direction.
Let's just
make believe
Let's make an imaginary water landing. First,
make yourselves as comfortable as possible.
Remove things which obviously could hurt
you-such as pencils, pens,
sharp jewelry.
Men, loosen your collars. Women, wriggle out
of those high-heeled shoes.
In the back of the seat in front of you, or in
the compartment indicated by your flight
attendant, is one of the latest lightweight life
jackets. Nylon, too. Slip it on according to
the following directions:
1 Pull tab to open container-
and remove life jacket.
2 Place life jacket
over head-put
hands through loops.
3 Pull tabs to tighten straps.
4 Black knobs inflate
jacket-do not pull
inside aircraft.
The life jacket
Mouth inflation tube:
screw in green collar-
push in mouthpiece—
blow to inflate.
Note! Used only after
inflation knobs are
pulled, it necessary
to inflate more.
Black knobs inflate
jacket. Do not
pull inside aircraft.
Pull-laos
Mouth
inflarion
tube.
Flap goes
behind back.
straps encircle waist.
A short time before any emergency water land-
ing, your Clipper Captain will give the order:
Brace for ditching. Adjust back of seat to for-
ward, vertical position, secure seat belt, extend
legs out straight, clasp your hands under your
knees and bend forward with head on lap as
nearly as possible. That, combined with the
cushioned seat, will relieve any sharp stop.
No doubt you've wondered what a water land-
ing feels like. The aircraft's belly will hit the
water first and you'll feel a slight jar ... then
the nose and wing sections will hit with a
greater jolt of about the intensity a navy pilot
feels on routine carrier landings.
When plane stops its forward motion, open your
seat belt and follow the next instructions of
your crew members to evacuate the aircraft.
After you are out of the aircraft pull the two
small knobs at the base of your life jacket.
They will inflate your jacket.
The Captain,
Co-pilot, Flight Engineer and
Purser will be in charge of the four rafts. Your
sea-going raft has adjustable sides and a sun
shade to protect you from sunburn and water
spray. During the late war some Army and
Navy fliers ditched their aircraft as many as
five times, without injury. It almost got to be
a habit…really not so dangerous as you might
think, but Pan American wanted you to know.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration
asks that every over-water
air passenger read this instructive
and interesting booklet ...
JUST IN CASE.

In case of emergency landing
REMEMBER THESE SAFETY RULES;
EXIT
Fire
Extinguisher
Oxygen
Know the location of your life
jackel-it's in back of seat in
front of you, or in compartment
indicated by your flight attendant.
EXIT
2
Loosen collar and tie. Remove
glasses and sharp objects from
pockets. Put on life jacket, if in-
structed, and fasten seat belt.
EXIT
EXIT
Adjust seat to vertical position.
Assume proper position to relieve
strain of possible shock.
EXIT
Never inflate your life jacket
inside cabin. Wait until you get
outside the plane.
Keep cool, calm and cooperative
until help comes. Follow instruc-
tions of your aircraft officers.
PRINTED IN U.S. A.
2011.126.534
